comment_text: Delta Air lines is the company for you if you want bad service. They make excuses for their bad service. They have bad customer service after you become a customer. Supervisor will hang up on you when you complain about their service. They give more respect to their bad employees than the customers who are paying them. Customer service believes that Delta Air lines has so many customers that it doesn’t matter if they run a few off.

My husband and I have had a gold Amex Skymiles card for years. I decided to upgrade to the Platinum card for the benefit of having a companion certificate once a year. We fly to Florida every January to cruise to the Caribbean and thought the $200/year difference in fees would be worth it. Wrong. Tried to book flights into Miami...no flights available. Tried to book into Ft. Lauderdale...no flights. Tried Orlando...nope. Tried Ft. Myers...nope. Companion certificates are absolutely worthless to where we fly to. Needless to say, we canceled the Platinum card after a month and went back to the Gold card. At least, until Delta stops accepting skymiles. Then the card will be gone and we will fly elsewhere.

I used to travel often for work. 80% of my travel was booked on United. The other 20% on others. I hated Delta flights back in the 1990s. Flights were rarely taking off on time claiming awaiting a delayed flight with connecting passengers. However, half the time if I had a connecting flight, I missed it because of the delay in taking off. Fast forward to 2005, delta got much better. They generally were on time, comfortable seating. Professional crew. Dealt with problems rapidly, and became more customer friendly. I like delta, although I don't like how they reduced perks for Gold and Platinum medallion members.

Since you won't answer my email, I will ask you to respond here. In January my luggage was lost and did not arrive with me to San Juan airport in Puerto Rico. When it arrived, I asked the a delta lost baggage representative if the round trip cost to travel to the airport to retrieve my bag would be reimbursed, and was told it would be. For some reason now your representatives have declined to reimburse me for this cost, and have sent me a link to a website that does not exist as an explanation for why. Please explain why I was told this would be covered and now is not. I do not want a flight credit- I want the cost of the expenses I submitted to pick up my bag to be added to my reimbursement payment. If I still do not receive a response I will file a complaint with the department of transportation.

Emergency and instead of the agents pulling the guest off of the flight immediately, Delta personnel made the decision to hold everyone over with no mention of what was happening until 45 minutes afterwards. However, after waiting and going back and forth for about an hour, the service rep across from b19 tried to assist with a room booking, but when we attempted to open the voucher we were given, we discovered it was null and void once we tried to check in and we had to now go back to the service/ ticketing desk in the baggage claim area of the airport this time. The agents there had us wait another hour and a half as they debated about the person in the b concourse, how they were ready to get off, someone having the ability to fix it but not wanting to do so, how the medical emergency wasn’t logged in their system, how they didn’t want to go behind what someone else’s work, whether they could give a paper or digital voucher, if they were going to give us one at all, shift duties, etc. Trying not to show my frustration with their conversation I continued to practice patience as my flight had landed around 840pm and it was close to midnight. A supervisor named Vonda finally cleared the hotel. However, when arriving to the airport in the morning we were still faced with the dilemma of getting our alcohol purchase through TSA, so I called customer service on the way back to the airport and explained, the customer service rep over the phone stated that we should be able to have a “red jacket” or supervisor walk us through TSA, but that was not the case. When we got to the service desk this time we were told we would have to purchase another bag/ luggage to put the alcohol items inside of at 7am…and then check the bag in or have our bags pulled so that we could put our items inside and recheck those bags in all with the possibility of missing another flight. With no time to go purchase luggage we chose the second option sprinting through the airport to get it done. Once we had our bags pulled we had to wait in another line to check them in again which took up a good amount of time, but after a long night and morning we were just happy to be home. However, this of course caused me to miss work and a job interview with little to easement besides it wasn’t Delta Air Lines fault. I said that to say a lot of the workers in the Atlanta airport seemed to need training and updates on procedures on what to do in these situations. I don’t think I’ll be flying with them again!

I love Delta but it must be the coldest airline in the world. Flew from Cape Town to Atlanta last night, and the temperature on the plane was unbearably cold. The passengers around me looked like they were dressed for sub-zero temperature with hoodies and blankets wrapped around their heads. The kitchen in the back where staff members sit is not so cold, but the poor passengers have to endure the cold. We often fly with other airlines around the world but no other airline is nearly as cold as Delta.

Obviously the airlines all need to improve customer service and comfort in flights. Flying is already uncomfortable and stressful and yet these airlines pack us in as tightly as possible like sardines, creating even more tension and discomfort within the plane. They provide no compassionate help when weary travelers are in need. These big companies lose their humanity and become only about numbers and profit. This needs to change. Even the AI summary of the reactions to the post are clarifying that people are very unhappy with the progression of airline service. It is a big issue and it is time we make stronger regulations for the airlines to follow.

Your commitment to customers has changed, I’ve been flying Delta Air Lines for years. My recent experiences were horrible, not just for myself but for my family as well. Our flight home was cancelled and instead of helping, Delta service agents yelled at me in front of my kids, lied about the reason for the cancellation, refused to help me find new flights and told me to figure out how to get home. I complained and get the same lie, canned responses and no accountability. I actually went to Alaskan Airlines and they helped me search for flights on Southwest. Use those airlines instead!
Congratulations on 100 years. Perhaps Delta might consider keeping their word to the remaining Flying Colonels and restoring our benefits. According to the award, we helped build the airline.

Unfortunately, my peace and opportunity for a break and a stress free few days has turned into an actual nightmare. Our flights got delayed. Our connections were missed, and instead of having sympathy or care for our situation the first two Delta agents we had to speak to literally yelled at us and told us there was nothing they could do to help us because the only flights available for four days were first class and under no circumstances do they offer rebookings as upgrades. They shooed us away to go pick up a desk phone to “get someone else to help” because there was nothing onsite Delta agents could do. We LITERALLY had to sit in the cold, depressing customer service lounge on the phone for four hours to find an option. The BEST option we were given was to take 5 flights to eventually reach our destination. I’m optimistic so I agreed. After two days of travel we arrived despite being humiliated that our connecting flights sky club lounge doesn’t accept stamped boarding passes any longer to honor 24 hour access. Then we arrived to our destination only to find that we will spend ANOTHER day without our clothes.
Happy Birthday Delta!!

We felt that Delta’s getting rid of MQMs was a bad move (especially for us as foreign members), but when they ended the roll over, that was even worse. Even with the horrible changes to MQDs over MQMs we would still return to premium status with our next flight to NY this new year. Imagine our surprise when we realized that Mr. Bastian had removed the rollover piece of the SkyMiles program as well. Let us ask you, what demonstrates more loyalty than longevity. The fact that we’ve been flying Delta and SkyTeam consistently for more than a decade demonstrates loyalty. Rolling over the MQDs is a way of rewarding continued flying and increasing retention. If you reset status every year without considering what’s been given in the past, it means more ‘What have you done for me lately?’ That’s a question to ask of someone working for you, not someone being loyal to you, someone that you’re working for. On top of all that, it doesn’t make any sense to anyone. We all know that getting new customers is far more expensive than retaining loyal ones, especially your shareholders.
